title: 108_hr4342
content: The Act is titled the "Scott Campbell, Stephanie Roper, Wendy Preston, Louarna Gillis, and Nila Lynn Crime Victims' Rights Act." It amends Title 18 of the United States Code to include a new chapter on Crime Victims' Rights. The "Crime Victims' Rights Act" outlines various rights for crime victims, including protection from the accused, notice of public proceedings, the right to be heard, confer with the government attorney, restitution, timely proceedings, and fair treatment. The "Crime Victims' Rights Act" ensures that crime victims are treated with fairness, dignity, and privacy in court proceedings. Government officials must make best efforts to notify and provide victims with the rights outlined in the Act, even in cases of conflict of interest between the prosecutor and the victim. The "Crime Victims' Rights Act" requires prosecutors to advise crime victims of conflicts of interest and provide legal referrals. Notice of release may be withheld if it endangers safety. Victims, their representatives, and the government attorney can assert rights under the Act, but accused individuals cannot benefit from it. In cases with multiple victims, the court may find it impracticable to address all their rights. If the number of crime victims makes it impracticable to accord all rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act, the court can create a procedure to implement the chapter. A Federal court's denial of a crime victim's right can lead to an application for a writ of mandamus to the court of appeals. The Government can challenge a district court's denial of a crime victim's right in a criminal case on appeal. The Crime Victims' Rights Act ensures crime victims' rights in legal proceedings related to the appeal. Failure to provide these rights does not warrant a new trial, and the act does not allow for a cause of action for damages. A crime victim is defined as someone directly harmed by a federal offense, with provisions for underage, incapacitated, or deceased victims. Legal guardians or representatives can assume the victim's rights, but the defendant cannot be named as such. Procedures are in place to promote compliance with the act. The Crime Victims' Rights Act mandates regulations to enforce and ensure compliance with crime victims' rights. This includes establishing an administrative authority to handle complaints and requiring training for Department of Justice employees who violate these rights. The Department of Justice must enforce Federal laws regarding the treatment of crime victims, provide training for employees, and impose disciplinary sanctions for non-compliance. The Attorney General has the final say on complaints with no judicial review. The Attorney General has the final say on complaints with no judicial review. SEC. 3. INCREASED RESOURCES FOR ENFORCEMENT OF CRIME VICTIMS' RIGHTS. Amends the Victims of Crime Act of 1984 to include Crime Victims Legal Assistance Grants. The Director may provide grants to various entities for the enforcement of crime victims' rights. Funds collected under the False Claims Act can also be used for these grants. Additionally, there are authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2005-2009 to carry out this Act. Authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2005-2009 include funding for Victim/Witnesses Assistance Programs, enhancement of the Victim Notification System, staff administration for the National Crime Victim Law Institute, and support for crime victims through the Department of Justice's Office for Victims of Crime. The Office for Victims of Crime of the Department of Justice provides support for the National Crime Victim Law Institute and similar organizations to offer counsel for victims in criminal cases and enforce crime victims' rights in Federal, State, and tribal jurisdictions. Increased resources are allocated to develop state-of-the-art systems for notifying crime victims of important dates and developments. The Victims of Crime Act of 1984 is amended to include provisions for notifying crime victims of important dates and developments. The Victims of Crime Act of 1984 is amended to include provisions for notifying crime victims of important dates and developments, including Crime Victims Notification Grants under SEC. 1404E. The Director may grant funds to various entities to develop and implement systems for notifying crime victims of important dates and developments related to criminal proceedings. These systems can be integrated with existing case management systems, and additional funds may be appropriated for this purpose. The False Claims Act allows for the use of funds collected under certain sections of title 31, United States Code, for grants under this section, subject to appropriation. $5,000,000 is allocated for fiscal year 2005, and $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2009. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts must report annually to Congress on the denial of rights in criminal cases under chapter 237 of title 18, US Code. The General Accounting Office will conduct a study on the impact of amendments on crime victims in the Federal system. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 3 years of the Act's enactment, detailing the study results conducted under subsection (a).
